abstract: Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk talk about a creative partnership that has taken them from "Nip/Tuck" to "Glee" to their new FX series, "American Horror Story," and why they're equally drawn to dark and light material.
snippet: Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk talk about a creative partnership that has taken them from "Nip/Tuck" to "Glee" to their new FX series, "American Horror Story," and why they're equally drawn to dark and light material.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years spent with the sunny kids of "Glee" could send anyone over to the dark side, and that's exactly where the "Glee" co-creators Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk turned for their latest television series, "American Horror Story," which makes its debut on Wednesday on FX. The new show begins with a husband and wife (Dylan McDermott of "The Practice" and Connie Britton of "Friday Night Lights") and their teenage daughter (Taissa Farmiga) moving to Los Angeles to start their lives fresh. But their new Gothic fixer-up was a steal for a reason: it's haunted by a history of murder and visited by creepy neighbors, housekeepers and unwelcome guests (including Jessica Lange, Frances Conroy and Denis O'Hare) as well as a mysterious figure in a full-body S&M costume, whom the "American Horror Story" producers have affectionately dubbed "Rubber Man."

headline.main: Don't Stop Screaming: The 'Glee' Guys Introduce Their 'American Horror Story'
